author: TomAlgie

description.text:
This is a simple 3-part lid that helps keep the spatter from the bubbling air through the etching solution inside the tank.
I still have to test it in practice, I hope the PLA survives the acidic spatter. It fits http://www.velleman.eu/products/view/?id=369500 this tank as is sold by velleman and also resold by various vendors around the world.

Print the 3 parts, 100% infill, 2 edges.
Carefully wedge the parts in place. It is quite fragile. Part 3 could use some support and comes out a little messy but it's still usable after a little cleanup.

comments.text: Awesome, just what I'm looking for. I'm also looking for a way to hold the PCB's in place while etching .. have you found a solution for that? I've used stiff plastic coated metal wire with tape before, but that's  definitely NOT ideal.
comments.author: Jossie90

comments.text: I still use the clips that came with the tank, on some stiff metal wire. It works fine for me.
comments.author: Jossie90

author: you_are_3D

description.text:
Rice cookers are awesome, but they come with a little plastic cup for measuring rice that is actually calibrated in an archaic Japanese unit of measurement called a Gō that doesn't match any other measuring cup in your kitchen. So if you lose the cup, you're kind of screwed.
It's really the ratio of rice and water that's important, but my rice cooker has marks inside the bowl for quantities that indicate number of little rice cups. So the little cup is super convenient but I didn't really feel like paying too much for a new cup or buying a new rice cooker. So I researched the right size (it's approximately 180 ml, or a bit more than 3/4 of a cup) and designed it in OpenSCAD.
You can change the base size, angle of the sides, thickness of the walls, and volume (if, say, you wanted to make a shot glass).

author: chev383

description.text:
Some day the squirrels are going to form a legion and seek out their vengeance.  On that day, you wouldn't want to get caught in the middle of the forest with an empty tin of pellets and no way to defend yourself.  That's where this handy piece of equipment comes in.  A bayonet for your pellet gun.  Don't let those tree rats get you without a fight!
This bayonet will fit any air gun with a barrel of 7/16" (11mm) outer diameter.  The two I have tested it on are the Crosman 2240 and the Benjamin Discovery.
I designed the hole slightly undersized so you can sand, dremel, or shave to the tightness you prefer.  With mine, I just stuck the blade of a knife straight in and twisted it a couple turns to shave the inside until it was a tight slip fit.  When I printed mine it goobered a little bit towards the tip.  I am thinking of making a slightly different version that doesn't have such a fine tip.
Added a second design.  Now with serrated blade!!

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.25

Infill:

25

Notes: You could probably print this with whatever shells and fill you like. I had mine set on 3 shells from a previous print and forgot to change it. It should print pretty quick. No need for support. There isn't much surface contacting the print bed so you might need a raft. My first one popped of the bed, but my second stuck. Neither had a raft.

description.text: This is a modern design take on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1282606 Rice cookers are awesome, but they come with a little plastic cup for measuring rice that is actually calibrated in an archaic Japanese unit of measurement called a Gō that doesn't match any other measuring cup in your kitchen. So if you lose the cup, you're kind of screwed. It's really the ratio of rice and water that's important, but my rice cooker has marks inside the bowl for quantities that indicate number of little rice cups. So the little cup is super convenient but I didn't really feel like paying too much for a new cup or buying a new rice cooker. So I researched the right size (it's approximately 180 ml, or a bit more than 3/4 of a cup) and designed it in OpenSCAD. And because I could, I made it all fancy minimalistic looking so that you could leave it on the counter without it looking like you didn't put away the rice cooker measuring cup. You can change the base size, angle of the sides, thickness of the walls, and volume (if, say, you wanted to make a shot glass).

Notes: ABS!!!

The 2016 BUTToN GEAR is here!
There are currently 6 styles uploaded.  There is the Token version, the Functional version and a big fun Special Edition version each with hole or slot attachment options.  As with all my designs these are guaranteed printable and have actually been printed and validated before uploading for your enjoyment.
The letters are larger than on the 2015 version for easier printing but these are fancier more complicated designs. A calibrated printer with a precisely leveled bed is required for good results.  Depending on the effectiveness of your part cooling fan and retraction settings various amounts of minor clean up may be required.
The STL files are CURA scaled and oriented for printing.  The options are available individually or as a single file download collection.
So don't delay!  Get your 2016 BUTToN GEAR!

Printer:

Rigidbot Big

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 mm

Infill:

20% - 30%

Notes: Use a calibrated filament. I use this one to calibrate each filament I use: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:103730.
0.4mm print head maximum.
Turn on retraction to minimize strings across the fine details.
A 0.2mm thick first layer helps to stick the small details to the bed when starting out.
A heated bed set at least to 60C for the first 0.5 of height and then turned down to 45C is recommended for PLA.
Part cooling fans come on at 0.3 - 0.4 and full speed at 0.5 when using PLA.
Top and bottom thickness recommended at 0.6 - 0.8mm.

author: chev383

description.text:
I am in the early stages of making a 3D printed clock.  Here, I'm sharing what I've learned about clock gears.  Typical gear teeth are involute.  Clocks are about the only place to find cycloidal gear teeth.  They are designed to run without lubrication and the small pinion gears can have fewer teeth than an involute gear.
Cycloidal teeth are actually simple.  The sides are radial lines from the hub of the gear.  The tip of the tooth can just be a semi-circle, instead of a cycloid.  The pinion teeth should be narrower than the 50% you'd expect in a gear tooth.
These gears are a 2:1 ratio.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Fast

I used 123D Design for these parts.  Begin with circles that represent the gears as though they were just rollers.  For my 2:1 gears, I used a 25mm and 50mm diameter.  The gears run on axes that are 37.5mm apart (25mm + 50mm)/2
Determine the angle that each tooth occupies on the circumference of the circle.  For a ten tooth gear, there are ten teeth and ten spaces.  360 degrees / 20 = 18 degrees.  However, for the smaller (pinion) gear, reduce that angle by 20% to create clearance.  This will result in backlash, but that is acceptable for a clock.  Fit a semi-circle for the tip of this tooth.  Draw radial lines from the semi-circle to the hub of the gear.  Create a circular pattern of this tooth for as many teeth as you had planned.  Terminate the radial lines to create tooth and space outlines.
Pinions can have as few as eight teeth, but ten teeth works better.
This is a simple gear train.  There are three sets of 2:1 ratios, for a total of an 8:1 ratio.  The higher the gear ratio, the more that friction and interference between parts will be evident.  This gear train was made to evaluate the gears, which ran very well, but did require some filing of the hubs after printing them.
The 20 tooth gears are 2mm thick.  The ten tooth pinion gears are 4mm thick.  There are two 1mm thick washers used for the assembly.  
Place the large diameter washer on one of the shafts, followed by the 20 tooth gear.
Place one of the other large gears, pinion down, on the other shaft.  Confirm that these two gears run well.
Place the other large gear, pinion down, above the single 20 tooth gear that rests on the washer.  Confirm that these three gears run well.
Place the 10 tooth gear on the other shaft.  Test the gears again.
Place the small diameter washer on the shaft that has the large washer on the bottom of the stack
Place the plate over the shafts and press the plugs into the hollow shafts to hold the assembly together.  The plugs may need filing before they'll press in.
Part Finishing I found the teeth printed very well, but the gear hubs needed to be filed a little to achieve the design dimension.

author: Leekwanghyun

description.text: I made this to start making some custom housings and mounts for the Go Pro Hero camera ( http://gopro.com/ ). This is not intended to be printed (although I guess you can if you really want) but is meant to building things for it and testing if it'll fit. This model is just the camera itself without the original waterproof housing that usually comes with the camera. Also includes the placement of the connectors, buttons and openings that may be important. I commented everything in OpenSCAD so you can turn things off easily and an "extrude" value to make the features stick out of the body father for better reference. I'm sure it's pretty accurate (used my own camera's measurements), so it should get you extremely close. Until I fully test it, I'll leave it as "Experimental"... Look for some cool housing designs soon...

Used for testing housing or mount designs for the Go Pro Hero camera without the waterproof housing.
If rendered in OpenSCAD, you will be able to see all the features colored.

comments.text: Thanks for this.  My wife is a keen amateur cyclist and has noticed that when she has our GoPro on her helmet motor vehicles give her a much wider berth.  She will wear this replica when she doesn't want to have the weight of the GoPro on her head.

title: Retrofit Micrometer Endstop Target for Taz 4/5

description.text:
A Mitutoyo 148-507 micrometer head will reportedly fit this one. I haven't personally tried it, but the person who tried it in my openbuilds Z axis mod (which uses identical micrometer support says that it will work fine)
1-21-2015 - Repaired file uploaded. 
I added a Micrometer to my openbuilds Z axis retrofit, and a few people have asked for a variant that will fit the stock Taz 4 / 5. Ths is that variant. You can see the Openbuilds version in the picture above. This one is basically the same thing, but has the socket for the 10mm smooth rod for a stock Taz.
The issue with the stock bolt and spring endstop target is that it can move with repeated impacts and heat and cooling cycles. Every time the limit switch hits it, it releases pressure on the threads, which allows the spring to sometimes press the bolt upwards a tiny fraction of a mm. Eventually, after a few hundred impacts, the bolt moves up far enough to screw with your layer height. 
By replacing it with a micrometer, you get an endstop target that will never move due to heat or impact, and allows repeatable layer height adjustments to the thousandth of an inch. 
I used this Micrometer here: <ebay link dead - removed>  which seems to be a knock of Mitutoyo of some sort, but any micrometer with a 9.7mm diameter, 6mm tall mounting barrel, 14mm  diameter retention ring and an at least 22mm long measuring shaft should work. A Mitutoyo 148-507  reportedly works but I have not tested it myself.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.5mm nozzle

Infill:

85% or better

Notes: ABS is reccommended

Instructions This print includes a built in Skirt and removable "mouse ears" to aid in bed adhesion. You will remove and discard those pieces at the end. You will need 1 M3 heat set insert for the Smooth rod retention bolt socket. Insert that as normal. The micrometer should just screw into place, then bolt the whole unit up as normal to your TAZ.

I keep my keys on a carabiner, which I keep clipped onto my belt loop. I often drop keys when clipping or unclipping the carabiner from my belt loop. However I frequently need to remove or add keys to the ring, so I don't want the keys to be too difficult to switch out. Hopefully this design works to my liking.  
Update: After a couple days of real-world use, I've uploaded a heavier-duty version, and one scaled just a bit larger.

Designed in Inventor 2011; printed in PLA on a Replicator 2 via Makerware 2.2.2.89 with "standard" settings; 3 shells, 100% infill, 234 degree extruder; 14 minute print time.
Heavier version took 23 minutes to print.

Needed some radius gauges bigger than 1/2" and those can get expensive.  These print about 1/16" thick and can be modified for other radii.  One of these scales up to 4.5" and the other to 5".  There is a small hole in the corner to tie them together.  I was going to make more, but these were the only two sizes I needed at the time.  Maybe later.

title: Pop Up Warning Sign - Bikes on Roof

description.text:
Tired of forcefully taking your bike off of your car's roof rack by driving it into your garage door? This aims to put an end to decapitated bikes everywhere. Sign mounts to your car's hood with magnetic strips. When traveling at speed, air moving over the car folds the sign closed. At low speeds or when stopping, springs pop the sign open, offering up a reminder that your bikes are still on the roof. Additional parts needed (with links): (3) 7/8" long, 1/8" diameter dowel pins
(http://www.mcmaster.com/#90145a474/=10ru635) (2) 90 degree torsion springs, .235" OD, .025" wire, left- or right-hand wound
(http://www.mcmaster.com/#9287k67/=10ru6kf) (27") 1" wide, 1/8" thick, adhesive-backed, high-pull magnetic strip
(http://www.mcmaster.com/#5769k82/=10ru84r) Model Notes:
I've included the parts with both tight tolerance dimensions as well low(er) tolerance dimensions for the dowel pin holes (I ended up needed to add a little slop to the holes to get the pins to fit nicely). Same goes for the offset of the letters. If you wanted to play it safe, you could start with the tight tolerance models and carefully open up the holes with a drill or shave down the edges of the letters, if needed. The top, base and letters are printed separately and then the letters are glued to the top panel using crazy glue or ABS slurry. For those with dual extruders or wishing to color the letters by hand, I've also included models with the letters already in place on the top panel. Printing Notes:
I used ABS for my prints. .2mm layer height, 25-40% infill (to add some mass to the panels). Letters are printed face down as it will provide a better cosmetic surface. Assembly notes:
As mentioned above, the letters are glued into place on the top panel. The magnetic strip is to be cut into 9" sections and installed 3-wide across the underside of the bottom panel. Use the dowel pins to secure the panels to each other; the springs get installed on the two outside hinges, run the dowel pin through the center of each.

author: chrisscholl

description.text: I love having a small oscilloscope on hand when troubleshooting my micro-controller projects, but due to its small size the DS202 can be cumbersome to use trying to hold the display at a viewable angle while also connecting the leads to your circuit. Enter this stand. The stand holds the DS202 at an angle for viewing and provides a place to stick the probes when not in use. I created both a one-piece design and a three-piece design that can be printed flat then fitted/glued together after the requisite sanding/Dremeling to make the parts inter-lock. I ultimately decided I liked the one-piece design best. Note: Since my pictures were taken I shortened the distance between the supports such that the Play/Pause button on the DS202 should be to the right of the right-side support. In my original design the support was just too close to the button. The STL and X3D files reflect the narrowed design.

Printer:

daVinci 1.0 Pro

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

15%

Notes: I printed this in ABS, and these are my print settings -- I do not believe they are necessarily ideal for the design. I would suggest tweaking to what you think will work best for your setup.

description.text: M3D SlimCD Door Hinge This is a hinge for a slim CD jewel case that will attach to the M3D printer. Print Settings: This was printed medium quality, medium fill, wave bond, raft, supports, and on model supports, rotated 45 degrees, and shifted slightly to fit on the print bed. Note: "Slim" jewel case, not the standard size. I have not tested it with that size case. This was inspired by someone on the M3D User Community FaceBook page that glued CD cases to his M3D.

comments.text: So the M3D is very touchy with temperature and anything blocking air flow helps. This is a step up from my saran wrap method. I printed 3 hinges no problem with high infill. I recommend putting something on the edges of the doors to dampen plastic on plastic rattling. I used hot glue.
comments.author: ferris

comments.text: What are you printing with? If your printing with PLA, then doing this wouldn't help. PLA wants extra cooling not less. This might help a little itsy tiny bit if your attempting to print with ABS, but without a heated bed there isnt any "heat" to hold in so not gonna be much of a difference, if any at all which is why I don't even consider ABS doable on the M3D. Stick with PLA, lots of cooling, blue tape for adhesion and this little printer does great. Cool little project tho and nice design work!
comments.author: MultiRotorManiac

comments.text: You keep posting this comment, but this does help with corners pulling up on PLA prints. There's still nothing covering the top, so cooling is fine. This simply stops cool air (from an air conditioner for example) from flowing through an active print.

Simple holder for 1kg spools.   
You will need two spool-center-parts and two side-parts printed. Additional needed (to fit spools with a width of 90mm and a diameter of 160mm): two 626-size bearings, three threaded rods M6 each 110mm long and 8 M6 nuts and 8 M6 washers.  
Just fix the left and the right holder-part with the nuts as shown in the last picture. Then you can drop the spool with the inserted spool-centers and the last threaded rod from the top into the stand.  
Normally the bearings should have a tough fit. If you like they can be fixed with three M3x10mm bolts and nuts on each side to prevent them from slipping out of the spool-centers.

author: chev383

description.text:
Note: I'm no longer working on this model. My future development will be focused on this one: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1411526 This is a remix of a remix. Florentf31's original FPV-190 design was for 18xx sized motors. The remix by btotherunner was for 22xx sized motors. I wanted to print that remix, but it was just barely too large for my printer's 200mm x 200mm bed. I moved the screw holes at the ends of the arms so it now fits. Only the parts changed are included here - the top, spacer, and bottom. Other parts such as camera mounts should be downloaded from btotherunner's or Florentf31's things. Original FPV-190 Racer by Florentf31: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1120168
Remix FPV-190 Racer by btotherunner: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1248646

title: FlashForge Dreamer Carriage Cover Plate With PTFE Sockets

description.text:
This Carriage Cover Plate allows you to connect 1/4" PTFE tubing to guide your filament into your extruders on the FlashForge Dreamer. I wanted to set up a drybox to keep my filament from absorbing moisture. After doing so, it became necessary to pipe the filament to the printer. This Cover Plate was the result. This plate snaps into place on your carriage. There are a few added/enhanced features:

  • Reinforced screw columns for mounting. If you look under the plate, you will see that I have broadened the base of the plastic columns which hold the screws.

  • Reinforced "front hook" that keeps the front of the plate hooked into the plastic housing that it snaps into.

  • Tubes that accept 1/4" PTFE tubing so you can run straight from your dry box, and decrease drag on your carriage.
    • Simply "Press Fit" the PTFE tubing into the Cover, and it will stay long term.

Printer:

FlashForge Dreamer

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.4 mm nozzle, .2 mm layer height

Infill:

100%

Notes: You will want to print this upside down. The detail that allows this part to snap fit into your existing carriage is very important. Without great detail, it won't fit. I used Simplify3d with 4mm support resolution. Abs temp 230. Speed 60mm/sec. Notice that my drybox is ABOVE my printer. If your drybox is LOWER than your printer, you may have issues with the tubes staying in. Also, you want to compensate for expansion and contraction. The printed X dimension of your final part needs to match the X dimension of 73.05 mm, (or 73 even).

This is an expansion set for my DNA / RNA Manipulative set that can be found at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1259352 This is a way to explore advanced topics in genetics, including mutation, protein formation, and nutrition. The main file is split into the essential and non essential amino acids. You can see how the protein you eat is recycled in your body into other proteins in your body. Lesson Plans and lab work is now available on my teacher pay teacher site, https://www.teacherspayteachers.com/Product/3D-Printable-DNA-RNA-Manipulative-Lab-1-3452084

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 - 0.3 mm

Infill:

5%

Notes: You can explore printing on a raft or brim. Break all sharp edges. If you are exploring the difference between essential and nonessential amino acids, print the files in two sets of colors.
Designed in TinkerCAD This was an expansion set designed from the same file as the DNA / RNA manipulative. You can substitute the AA block for these Amino Acids.

Project: Amino Acid Expansion Set This is to expand upon the DNA / RNA manipulative set I made to study genetics. With the 20 Amio Acid blocks here, you can explore bio chemistry and coding for the proteins in our body. This will work for AP Biology or College biology class. Objectives Students will explore how proteins are formed from amino acids.
Students will explore how amino acids are coded.
Students will demonstrate are proteins are formed from DNA.
Students will demonstrate mutation and show the various types.
Students will learn the essential and nonessential amino acids.
Students will examine nutrition and explore where they get amino acids from.
Students will examine the claims of dietary supplements to see if their needed for part of a diet.
Students will explore genetic disorders and how they are formed from changes in amino acids.
Students will examine how the environment can impact our genes. Audiences This is for High School, AP Bio, or College Biology students. Preparation Print the DNA / RNA manipulative set first.
You can have students work in groups of 2. Print at least one full set of amino acids. If you discuss essential & non essential amino acids, print them separately in two colors to distinguish the two. Print a table of amino acids and their codes, which can be found at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amino_acid Have your students understand the code for the amino acid blocks. Have your class practice coding and transcribing DNA to RNA using the previous DNA / RNA manipulative. Have them use a RNA coding table to build a protein from tRNA. Steps a. Review DNA / RNA transcription.
b. Learn the 1 letter codes for each of the amino acids.
c. Practice transcribing DNA to RNA, and using the tRNA block produce the amino acid that is coded.
d. Use the amino acids to build a simple protein.
e. Demonstrate and have the students show what happens if there is a mutation.
f. Demonstrate the different types of mutations.
g. Use this to discuss or examine different genetic disorders, and what causes them. Model the mutation (if possible) that causes this genetic disorder.
h. Explore how you could modify or edit genes with this model.
i. Explore how artificial life has been created.
j. Explore ethical topics in genetics, modeling them with these models. Results Students should demonstrate how proteins are formed from DNA.
Students should demonstrate mutations.
Students should understand the cause of genetic disorders.
Students should understand the nutrients involved in genetics.
Students should critically look at nutrition, and at the claims they see on the media for diet supplements.

author: chev383

description.text:
Needed this for a particular sized spool but figured I would make it parametric. Was quite an easy project actually. Essentially the same as the spool by "caru" (didn't see that). I do plan to make some additions such as a semi-transparent dome top to put LEDs and a cover for the outside of the solenoid. I FINALLY have access (sort of) to a 3D printer but alas it's not functioning right now...figures. It's a replicator 2 and I guess it's under warranty which is why they haven't just turned it over to me to fix! Still trying to convince my own boss to get us one - she needs convincing for some reason... I guess "limitless potential" just doesn't cut it.  
It would be nice if the two pieces screwed together (or clipped together) but I'm not sure how to do a screw with OpenSCAD. The extrude and twist is just too unpredictable. I'll be looking into it when I have time, since the printer isn't working anyway I'm not rushing it. Any suggestions would be appreciated. For example how do you replicate a 1/4-20 with accuracy?   
The actual use for this is to demonstrate how waves (water) can make energy. There is a bobber - like a toilet bobber - that bounces up and down giving about an inch to an inch and a half range of motion and I'm just trying to get enough voltage to power an LED but haven't been successful thus far. Couldn't find a spool with the right diameter so why not just print one! With a zener diode and capacitor we got it to work but the speed needed just won't cut it with the previous coils I made. So this will be take 2 (or 3). If it doesn't work at least I made the effort to make it adjustable. If I can't get the juice I need I'll have to go rotary. Again, any suggestions are welcomed and appreciated.

description.text:
I participated in a kickstarter campaign to fund the pulse sensor: http://pulsesensor.com/. I recieved it and it's great but I thought it would be nice to make an autonomous heart rate monitor.
So I added to my arduino a Nokia 5110 LCD that you can get from Sparkfun, adafruit or ebay. After some coding I had a nice heart rate monitor with text and some nice graphics and thought I should make a case to make it even nicer. After a few minutes in sketchup I had a case for the LCD that I am sharing today. I also included the arduino code if somebody is interested it is based on the code from the creators of the pulse sensor and the excellent Nokia 5110 library from adafruit (https://github.com/adafruit/PCD8544-Nokia-5110-LCD-library). Added a variant using TV Out for those which do not have a LCD screen. you will need the TV Out libraries that you can find on http://code.google.com/p/arduino-tvout/

• Print
  • Push LCD in Case
  • Wire LCD and Pulse Sensor to Arduino
  • Add Adafruit librairie to your Arduino Environnement
  • Compile and Upload to Arduino
  • Enjoy
    • OR Alternative for TV version
  • Wire TV Out and Pulse Sensor to Arduino
  • Add TV Out librairie to your Arduino Environnement
  • Compile and Upload to Arduino
  • Enjoy

description.text: This is a small generic pulley I designed which can be used for many applications. I designed and printed it for raising and lowering some flourescent light fixtures.

This prints well with a 3D printer down to 50% of original size. I'm using a Replicator 2. I've printed at 100%, 75% , and 50% (pictured). For print settings of 100% and higher you can use 3 shells and a 40% infill for added strength. For smaller than 100%, 2 shells and 15% infill is adequate. Print time at 75% is 33 minutes. The cotter key fits quite snugly - and a pair of pliers can be used to gently lock it onto the pin.  
No supports are necessary. As you can see in the drawing, I added spokes to the wider part of the pulley wheel so that the printer can transition to the wider area without the need of additional support.

With one hole for a screw in the center of the circle, and holes every 10mm for a pencil.

Print these to hold your spools neatly outside the case. Designed to allow full opening of the lid with spools loaded. Uses a length of 1/2" metal conduit at least 13.5" long. Simply grabs onto the factory plastic case for a very snug and strong fit. The left side may need some carving up if you have a davinici 1.0 like mine. I also carved a narrow slot into the back of the lid to allow a kink-free pass through.

Infill:

50%

title: Multiple Device Charger
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: The device charger is a great way of organizing your smart devices as well as keeping them charged and ready for use. The charger is made from 4 mm plywood and designed to be lasercut making it possible to have a single piece front that is bent into shape.
You can find a detailed walk-through of how to make and assemble the device charger on our website: Building a multiple device charger

We added a single device edition of the charger with the parts prefixed "Single Slot"
You will have to do some modifications yourself as how to mount the needed parts inside.
Preperation

Remember that this project requires you to work with mains power, and that you will be connecting your valuable USB device to it. So if you are new at this or unsure how it works, then consider waiting with making this project. Before you start making your own device charger, make sure you have all the parts on the shopping list (Found below here). Assembly The charger is assembled by clicking the parts together and using hot glue to make the parts stick. Remember that the power supply needs to be inserted before support is added on both sides and the USB Breakout mount needs to be added before both sides plates are added. Once again you can find a detailed walk-through of how to make and assemble the device charger on our website: Building a multiple device charger

You will need the following components
  • 8 x USB Cables
  • 8 x USB Breakout boards
  • 1 x Power socket
  • 1 x IEC 320 C13 Power cable
  • 1 x Fuse for the power socket, 0.5 A should be enough.
  • 1 x Volt meter
  • 1 x 5 pin terminal block
  • 16 x 3 mm spacers OR a piece of 3 mm acrylic
  • 16 x M3 Bolts
  • 16 x M3 Nuts
  • A large piece of 4mm plywood
  • A role of masking tape
  • Some shrink tubing
  • Small piece of 3 x ~1.5 mm² wire
  • Some black and red ~0.5 mm² wire
    • You will need access to the following tools
  • A laser cutter capable of cutting the 4mm plywood
  • A hot glue gun
  • A utility knife
  • Lighter/Blowtorch
  • Soldering iron

I publish this but it's not finished project and I will not work to finish it. By printing all parts and some drill job it flyes perfect, but in my opinion it's a little big and heavy and i'm working in a 220 class tilt arm version. This is a first test video fly:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GFe7Fs5_32g This is how it moves the arms:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WvURjdxvo6I This is a video recorded with a mobius mounted in flight with 330 tilt:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rLdhbNzQayw Full part list to print:
2 units of mainplate
2 units of Arm to servo linkage
1 unit of servo case
1 unit and a half of camera protection (front protection and 2 joint units)
4 units of arm support
1 unit arm spacer
4 units of Arm support Also you need some hardware: 4 ball bearings 18x12x4 mm. I use this http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewItem.asp?idProduct=75522 12 units spacer 35mm. The ones used in micro frames like ZMR250. I use those: http://www.banggood.com/10PCS-M35-M320-M335-Inner-Thread-Round-Aluminum-Pillar-Spacer-Red-For-Multicopter-QAV250-PC-Board-p-1002052.html Carbon or aluminium tube 12 mm diameter, the lenght is what you want 1 Servo metal gears. I like fast and with torque. I used this: http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewitem.asp?idproduct=19959 Linkage stopers: http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewItem.asp?idProduct=43160, Metal push rods http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewItem.asp?idProduct=63710 and screws m3x10

A tool that simplifies the process of combining multiple STLs into a single file for larger volume 3D printing. Using OpenSCAD, the user can define their build volume, import multiple STLs, and position them around in 3D space without having to write the code by hand. Editable Parameters:
Position from center(mm): x,y,z
Rotation about axis(degrees): x,y,z
Mirror about plane: x,y,z For strategies on creating printing plates efficiently, there is a good writeup on the MakerBot blog: http://www.makerbot.com/blog/2011/09/19/how-to-make-a-printing-plate/

• Open printing-plate.scad with OpenSCAD
  • Save and rename a copy into a directory containing STLs
  • Below "BUILD AREA", adjust maximum dimensions for each axis specific to your machine
  • Change the name of "< filename1 >" to match a file in the directory of STLs
  • Input positional coordinates, rotational angle, and/or mirror plane as specified in the comments.
  • Save file and choose "Design->Reload and Compile" within OpenSCAD to get quick visual feedback of your changes.
  • Repeat steps 4-6 until all files are correctly positioned (max 10 STLs)
  • Choose "Design->Compile and Render (CGAL)" and wait
  • Export as new multi-part STL
  • Print!

remixed_from.title: DremelFuge - A One-Piece Centrifuge for Rotary Tools

description.text:
This is a fork of the original DremelFuge. There are two improvements, the most important is on safety. The centrifuge tube is locked in and cannot escape. The second one is the compatibility with different centrifuge size tubes. You have to measure the diameter of the tube, as shown on the picture and choose the right centrifuge tube plate part. A Dremel can reach 30000 rpm, so it's appropriate for all biology experiments.
This design has been tested at 30000 rpm, it works. When you use this device, you have to put the mobile parts into a solid box to prevent injuries (if it breaks).
Never forget to take the adequate safety precautions (safety glasses, ...). See the video on youtube https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iu3Eb0hpVNM

title: ROLLER GUIDE SYSTEM
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I'm developed and design roller system - fitted to case W: 28cm H: 28cm, because many plastics bags with breads looks horrible! Now my kitchen looks more luxury! No more bags looks out from the case! I'm tried to do an optimized shape for 3D printing, especially is setup for 0.4 nozzle system. 2 times drive around the shape and next layer. Optimized for the nozzle, speed, material needs. You can find parts:
1 Guide: rails, turns, ends
1 Roll: Mainpart, Holder+end, Closure End part I made a bigger portfolio of formats for you. Designed in Autodesk Inventor.
Formats: .igs, .stp .ipt Version 1: Shape = S / 0.8mm of Shell / no problem for printing stability!
Version 2: Is not stable for printing, in higher positions is melted by the extruder. I will work on it to optimize! Printing time and process:
Based on quality what was required is printing time really low and used a middle fan. Bigger transport speed can drop down the parts, especially big risky is in the higher places of the part! Material: Colorfabb black PLA
Layer: 0,1mm
Temperature: between proposed temp from producer of material
Time: 1Roll: 3,45hours
I advise doing bigger BRIM for better sticking to bed. I'm printed:
ROLLS: 32 + 2 holders + 2 closures
GUIDE RAILS: 12 mid + 12 end + 4 turn
In total aprox 70 hours of printing. So, I hope that will helpfully also for your open cases at your home! In further question feel free to contact me. Would be nice if you will connect on my facebook page, which is actualized with freshly printed things and photos!
https://www.facebook.com/3D.obiecto/ Thank you
Efliq from 3D Obiecto!

Printer:

Mankati Fullscale XT

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm
Requirements I'm wants to do an optimized shape for 3D printing ROLL system, optimized for 0.4mm nozzle system.

description.text:
Smarthome mqtt switch. With 4 touch buttons and one or two rgb LEDS. This to covers are for Busch/Jäger standard program. But you can print your customized covers for your switch system. I think it works only with German/EU switch programs. ESP SW: https://github.com/hexxter/ESP8266_UP_switch The switch can be used as a original mechanical switch replacement. But it has 4 button and only one 220V 5A power switch. In my case the Button1 is Alarm and switch on the lights around my house. Button2 switch on the main room light over the power switch. Button 3 switch on an indirect light (white) and Button 4 enable my rgb light.
For Button3 and 4 i use this box: http://de.aliexpress.com/item/RGBWW-Strip-WiFi-Controller-1-Port-Control-200-Lights-Communicate-with-Android-Phone-Via-WLAN-to/32502007408.html As backend i use this with mosquito as mqtt broker: https://home-assistant.io/ BOM:
Powersupply:
  • http://de.aliexpress.com/item/5pcs-AC-DC-85V-265V-700mA-Isolated-Switching-Power-Board-Module-Industrial-Power-Supply-Built-in/2054274081.html
    • Touch (see pictures you can solder some metal on the edge pins i use chopper wires for touch field):
  • http://dirtypcbs.com/view.php?share=15460&accesskey=1b1a437a41eb1534f14b488f33c2cf78
  • http://de.aliexpress.com/item/5PCS-TTP224N-BSB-TTP224-SSOP16/32432360351.html
  • http://de.aliexpress.com/item/WS2812B-4pins-5050-SMD-W-WS2811-Individually-Addressable-Digital-RGB-LED-Chip-FREE-SHIPPING/1594023008.html
  • abstandsrahmen_touch_pcb.stl you can glue it on the bottom side of the touch pcb for better isolation to the metal plug frame.
  • ds18b20 for room temp.
    • ESP8266 (cut in to 2 parts see pictures you must bridge GND and one IO to the 220V switch) :
  • http://www.esp8266-projects.com/2015/04/p2-wifi-web-power-switch-for-mains-mpsm.html

description.text: Hang your Favorite keychain. With this handy Keyring
A box that grabs the base with hooks on planetary gears. Unlike most sets of planetary gears, this has no sun gear; instead, a triangle holds the three in place relative to each other.

Printer:

M3D Micro

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

Low

Notes: The lid consists of all pieces except the base. All pins simply pop into place. The base can be printed with no support if your bridging is good enough (I suggest printing it top-down to print the gear teeth correctly). There will be some wobbling of the pins when assembled correctly. Edit: The pin plate has new pins that are much less wobbly. You should insert them through the lid and then into the gears for easier and nicer-looking assembly, although you can do it either way.

author: zagor1970

description.text:
EDIT 2017-04-29:
I'm adding a zip file with the .scad drawings and two .scad libraries you need to add in the same directory to use some module.
those libraries are:
-a pin library slighty modified by me, but I don't remember which was, maybe this: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:33790
-a herringbone rack library slightly (and badly) modified by me to eliminate the body. the original library can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6011 The code has comments at the beginning to print every single part, I'm sorry you have to find out how many prints for every piece, but I think it will be simple. Have a nice day! I'm interested in building a flat printer, similar to N.Seward design: https://plus.google.com/u/0/+NicholasSeward/posts/d2vhGGjsFVt?pid=6039614550851948914&oid=104209901845806192943 ..so this is an attempt to see if a rigid chain is doable with 3d printing..
I'm not uploading Openscad files until someone is interested in improving it, because it doesn't work very well...
I posted pictures all the way, because it can be of inspiration for someone. Inspired by:
http://www.serapid.fr/fr/theatre/th_app_av_fr.html
http://mymechatronics.pbworks.com/w/page/76547795/Telescoping%20Linear%20Actuator Hi, Davide.

if this is used for z-axis of a plane, the little tolerance of every single pin is brought to zero by the gravity.
The problem with this design is not the tolerance, as I can see, but the movement which is not fluid.
One should redesign the "tunnel" so that there is a more fluid guide for the chain to exit and come back in.
Like I designed is too simple, since it was just the first try, so it blocks every chain module...

title: Small Footprint CoreXY Y Carriage (derrivative of Smartrapcore) :: X rods are end-supported and clamped, linear bearings are clamped

description.text:
See the 3D Model in a better viewer than thingiverse's at Sketchfab: https://sketchfab.com/models/b88a3147d5fb47189e2bd58f871331e8/embed

This is a design of an Y Carriage for a CoreXY I am building.
It uses 8mm rods for the X axis and 10mm rod for Y axis. The bearings are 608s.
Note: the diameter of the rods has been calculated based on their unsupported length and the weight of the parts they'll be supporting. More details you can find on reprap forums.
The X rods' back-rest bolts are M4 and the lower bolt is intended to clamp both the LM10UU bearings while also providing support for the lower X rod. The X rods are clamped using M3 bolts/nuts. Extra rigidity comes from the side wall, which is the side you will print this thing on

description.header: Update 10/06/2016: Uploaded an 8mm (LM8UU) version by just filling the gap between the LM10UU hole for the bearings and the LM8UU diameter. Also attached the RSDOC file with both designs. NOTE: PLEASE check the RSDOC and do the measurements so it fits your design!!!
description.text: I must say that this is my slickest design to date for "CoreXY" Y Carriage with Vertical Stacked X rods.

[Older updates] Update 12/04/2016: I did an overhaul of this design, changing some of its core features: I have managed to get both rods back-supported. The solution is easy to see in the attached images. Update 11/04/2016: It has been brought to my attention that any plastic carriage for Y axis that is not offering a solid back-rest for the X rods will be suffering of Y rods flexing due to the tension in the belts. The X rods in the current design don't stop flush with any wall, instead they are clamped with plastic features via M3 bolts/nuts. This might be sufficient as the Smartrapcore proves (is it?) but I will be migrating to designs that can sport back-screws for the X rods's ends. I have updated the STL as well as attached the RSDOC (DesignSpark Mechanical) source file for the "SmoothRod-Backrest" version, where only the upper rod is back-supported by an M3 bolt. The lower rod should be flush with the plastic wall, as shown in the attached pictures. You can read a bit more about this at: http://forums.reprap.org/read.php?397,650342,650430#msg-650430 Update 24/03/2106: New version: got rid of M8 bolt (too massive, heavy) and replaced it with M5 bolt + M5 Round Coupler (OD 8mm), the washers and 608 bearings remain for this version. Both STL & .RSDOC uploaded. Update 04/03/2106: New tweaked file uploaded together with the RSDOC for easy CAD (true geometry) editing. Update 23/02/2015: If you are printing in PLA, the previous design might have been too easily to break for the rod clamping lips. I think I might have forced it too much though, as I tried to touch the two lips without the rod so the flex was too much for PLA to take. As a result, I have reinforced a bit the thin side at the rod hole level, as you can observe from the attached update. Update 18/02/2015: I have uploaded a corrected design for the Y carriage, one that has a bit larger gap for the two 608 bearings and the washers that will prevent the outer race of the bearings to make contact with the plastic or with each other. I have also added a second hole for the mirrored carriage, a hole that was missing from the previous design. Another modification is the curved cut that makes easier the opening or closing of the smooth rods receiving hole as it was pretty difficult to clamp in the previous version. Update 24/01/2015: For the less precise printers, which can't ensure very accurate hole sizes (which are an absolute requirement to clamp at the same time the 8mm X rod and the linear bearing), I have uploaded Ver2, which has one screw per hole. The M8 bolt still performs two functions, clamping the linear bearings as well as being the shaft for the 608 bearings, while the 8mm rods are clamped by M3 bolts/nuts. With this design the Y carriage can be pushed very close to the frame. The orientation of the print is the same with the first version, on the flat side. The 8mm holes are exact while the linear bearings hole is a tad larger than the LM10UU OD. It doesn't matter much with the slots that allow for diameter variations accommodation as well as easy insertion. The Nut insert holes are also exact and I recommend hot insertion of the nuts.

description.text: This is a Trammel of Archimedes ( http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trammel_of_Archimedes ), drawn from scratch after seeing another printed version, presumably Thing 5103. Drawn from scratch as an exercise in Alibre, where the '2' designates this is really v2 with filleted corners to make it easier to hold and where the elliptical path just barely misses the guide. When printing raftless with ABS, if you have it too close to the platform the bottom layer might be flattened to too big to fit into the slot and you'll need to perform surgery to cut it off. The model can be improved to account for this but these are the original STL's I printed. Motion is very smooth if printed with PLA - see http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rSmlT-N9rQM Edit : Updated the slider with a chamfer on the base for raftless prints which I often do.

1)Print (The settings I used for Up! are 0.2mm layers, 'fine' and solid/loose fill)
2)Slot the sliders in
3)Put the arm onto the sliders
4)Play during a long meeting The sliders have a 2.4 hole, where you can tap your own M3 thread and attached a thumbscrew on top to hold the arm in. I found that this wasn't necessary with the black ABS and clear PLA versions I printed using the Up!. Edit : You don't actually need to tap it!!! Just screw in your M3 threaded screw in! Most PC screws are M3, I used gold thumbscrews :)

This is cool and fun to look at.

Project: Perpetual Motion Machine Objectives: Students don't learn much, other than the science of perpetual motion and that a device like this cannot actually exist due to the laws of thermodynamics. Audiences: All ages can enjoy this Preparation: - Need 8 marbles or small metal / heavy balls
Students should know that devices like this cannot actually exist. Energy cannot be created or destroyed. This device, if it could rotate forever, would violate the first and second laws of thermodynamics. Steps:
  • Make it
  • Buy the 8 balls
  • Load the balls into the crescents
  • Start the rotation
  • Voila!
    • Results: Students should have a brief understanding of the laws of thermodynamics after creating this.

comments.text:
Hi Lil!
Thank you for sharing your utopia !
Your design is great but not easy to print... hangover in the ball path make the way a bit wobbly (I print horizontal)
and the protruding axles as they are generate a lot f friction.
Could you modify the design so that the path of the ball is less than 45° or better spherical, and just use a 2mm diameter hole for a steel rod to be inserted? like this model but with your sectional geometry http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:44185/#comments. This one looks good but the geometry is incorrect
Did you print one? I will post the current print, scaled to accommodate 8mm balls
Thanks!
